description: Tomatillo, also known as Mexican husk tomato, is a member of the nightshade family native to Mexico and Central America. It produces small, round fruits enclosed in papery husks. Tomatillos have a tart, citrusy flavor and are a key ingredient in many Mexican and Latin American dishes, including salsa verde and various sauces. They are easy to grow and can be harvested when the husks turn brown and the fruits fill out.
varieties: Tatsoi, also known as spoon mustard or spinach mustard, is a leafy green vegetable with tender, spoon-shaped leaves and a mild, mustard-like flavor. It is commonly used in salads, stir-fries, and soups. While there are not as many recognized varieties of tatsoi as other vegetables, some common types include 'Tatsoi Rosette', known for its compact growth habit and vibrant green leaves, and 'Tatsoi Savoy', which offers heavily ruffled leaves and a sweeter taste. These varieties provide options suited for different culinary preferences and growing conditions.

sowingAndPlanting.sowingIndoorsDescription: Tatsoi is best sown directly outdoors rather than started indoors. However, if you want to get a head start on the growing season, you can start tatsoi seeds indoors in biodegradable pots or trays filled with seed-starting mix. Plant seeds 1/4 inch deep and space them 1-2 inches apart. Keep the soil consistently moist and warm (60-70°F). Transplant tatsoi seedlings outdoors once they have developed several true leaves and the weather has warmed up.
sowingAndPlanting.sowingOutdoorsDescription: Tatsoi seeds should be sown directly outdoors as soon as the soil can be worked in the spring. Choose a location with partial shade to full sun and well-drained soil. Plant seeds 1/4 inch deep and space them 4-6 inches apart in rows spaced 12-18 inches apart. Keep the soil consistently moist until seedlings emerge.
sowingAndPlanting.season: Tatsoi prefers cooler weather and should be planted in the early spring or late summer for a fall harvest. It can tolerate light frosts and may even overwinter in mild climates.

careAndMaintenance.growingDescription: Tatsoi prefers partial shade to full sun and well-drained, fertile soil with a pH of 6.0-7.0. It requires regular watering to keep the soil consistently moist, especially during dry periods. Mulch around plants to conserve moisture and suppress weeds.
careAndMaintenance.wateringNeeds: Regular watering, aiming for 1 inch per week.
careAndMaintenance.soilFertility: Incorporate compost or well-aged manure into the soil before planting to improve fertility and soil structure. Side-dress tatsoi with a balanced fertilizer once it starts growing vigorously.

harvestingAndStorage.timeToMaturity: Tatsoi typically matures and is ready for harvest 30-40 days after planting, depending on the variety and growing conditions.
harvestingAndStorage.storageRecommendations: Harvest tatsoi when the leaves are young and tender, usually before they start to bolt (produce flowers). Use a sharp knife or scissors to cut the outer leaves, allowing the inner leaves to continue growing. Store harvested tatsoi in the refrigerator for up to a week.
harvestingAndStorage.harvestDescription: Harvest tatsoi when the leaves are large enough to use, usually when they are 4-6 inches long. Cut the outer leaves first, leaving the center leaves to continue growing. Rinse the tatsoi thoroughly to remove any soil before storing or using it.

goodCompanionPlants.name: Marigolds
goodCompanionPlants.description: Marigolds are good companions for tomatillos. They can help repel pests like nematodes, aphids, and tomato hornworms due to their strong fragrance and natural insecticidal properties.

goodCompanionPlants.name: Basil
goodCompanionPlants.description: Basil is a beneficial companion for tomatillos. It can enhance the flavor of tomatillos and may help repel pests like aphids and spider mites.

goodCompanionPlants.name: Onions
goodCompanionPlants.description: Onions make good companions for tomatillos. They can help deter pests like aphids and whiteflies, and their pungent smell may confuse and repel pests.

goodCompanionPlants.name: Garlic
goodCompanionPlants.description: Garlic is a beneficial companion for tomatillos. It can help repel pests like aphids, spider mites, and whiteflies, while also adding flavor to nearby plants.

goodCompanionPlants.name: Nasturtium
goodCompanionPlants.description: Nasturtiums are beneficial companions for tomatillos. They can help repel pests like aphids, whiteflies, and cabbage loopers, and their bright flowers attract beneficial insects to the garden.

badCompanionPlants.name: Potatoes
badCompanionPlants.description: Potatoes are not recommended as companions for tomatillos. Both belong to the nightshade family and are susceptible to similar pests and diseases. Planting them together may increase the risk of pest infestations and diseases.

badCompanionPlants.name: Fennel
badCompanionPlants.description: Fennel may not be an ideal companion for tomatillos. Fennel produces chemicals that inhibit the growth of nearby plants, which can negatively affect the growth and yield of tomatillos.

badCompanionPlants.name: Cabbage
badCompanionPlants.description: Cabbage may not be a suitable companion for tomatillos. Both plants have different growth habits and nutrient requirements, and planting them together may result in competition for resources and reduced yields.

badCompanionPlants.name: Sunflower
badCompanionPlants.description: Sunflowers may not be ideal companions for tomatillos. Sunflowers have deep taproots that may compete with tomatillos for water and nutrients, and their tall stature may overshadow and shade tomatillo plants.

badCompanionPlants.name: Fruit Trees
badCompanionPlants.description: Fruit trees, such as apple or pear trees, may not be suitable companions for tomatillos. Fruit trees have different growth habits and nutrient requirements, and planting them together with tomatillos may result in competition for resources and reduced yields.

tipsAndTricks: Choose a planting site with well-drained soil and full sun exposure.
Prepare the soil by adding compost or aged manure to improve fertility and texture.
Plant tomatillo transplants in the garden after the last frost date, spacing them 2-3 feet apart in rows spaced 3-4 feet apart.
Water tomatillos regularly, providing about 1-2 inches of water per week, and mulch to conserve moisture and suppress weeds.
Fertilize tomatillos with a balanced fertilizer or compost tea every 3-4 weeks, following package instructions.
Stake or cage tomatillo plants to support their sprawling growth habit and keep fruits off the ground.
Monitor plants regularly for signs of pests such as aphids and flea beetles. Use row covers or insecticidal soap as needed.
Watch for symptoms of diseases like early blight and powdery mildew. Provide good air circulation and avoid overhead watering to reduce humidity around plants.
Harvest tomatillos when the husks turn brown and papery and the fruits fill out, typically 70-80 days after planting. Twist or cut the fruits from the stems and remove the husks before using.
